messages.text:
I was recently confronted with the fact that a Project.toml and Manifest.toml are not necessarily sufficient for reproducibility of a project if they are dependent on a `dev`'d package. In retrospect, that's not a surprise, but it wasn't on my mind since I had a mental heuristic that "checked in Manifest = reproducible"

So if a package is `dev`'d, that's out, are there any other cases where this would be true? Eg, if I have only `add`'d packages, but some aren't in a registry, are there any ways in which a dependency graph might include something that can't be retrieved? It looks like if I do `add` but point to a local path, this is the same as doing `dev`?

The only other example I could think of was git history-destroying operations, but barring that, what am I missing?

elements.text: I was recently confronted with the fact that a Project.toml and Manifest.toml are not necessarily sufficient for reproducibility of a project if they are dependent on a
dev

'd package. In retrospect, that's not a surprise, but it wasn't on my mind since I had a mental heuristic that "checked in Manifest = reproducible"

So if a package is

add
'd packages, but some aren't in a registry, are there any ways in which a dependency graph might include something that can't be retrieved? It looks like if I do
add
but point to a local path, this is the same as doing
dev

?

The only other example I could think of was git history-destroying operations, but barring that, what am I missing?

messages.text: Having worked with package managers from Ruby (`gem`, good) and Python (`pip`, bad) I appreciate the amount of thought that went into the design of Julia's `Pkg`.  After creating a few of my own packages (some of which will eventually be ready for public consumption) I have a few questions:

elements.text: Having worked with package managers from Ruby (
gem
, good) and Python (
pip
, bad) I appreciate the amount of thought that went into the design of Julia's
Pkg
.  After creating a few of my own packages (some of which will eventually be ready for public consumption) I have a few questions:

messages.text: 1. Rubygems handled not only library functionality (like `Pkg`) but also command line utility scripts.  What is the best way to distribute command line utility scripts that are associated with a Julia pacakge?

elements.text: Rubygems handled not only library functionality (like
Pkg
) but also command line utility scripts.  What is the best way to distribute command line utility scripts that are associated with a Julia pacakge?

messages.text: 2. When should the `Manifest.toml` be version controlled?  It seems like it should be committed for projects that are intended for a specific task (for recreatability), but it seems maybe overly prescriptive to commit it for a package.

elements.text: 2. When should the
Manifest.toml

be version controlled?  It seems like it should be committed for projects that are intended for a specific task (for recreatability), but it seems maybe overly prescriptive to commit it for a package.

messages.text: 3. Is it possible to have a `[compat]` entry that specifies a specific git repo and commit for a dependent package?  My use case for this is HDF5. v0.14.3 has a feature that I need, but also a bug that was fixed in a subsequent commit but is not yet in a tagged version.  I know this info is captured in the `Manifest.toml` file, but that includes lots of additional details that don't seem necessary (see previous question)

elements.text: 3. Is it possible to have a
[compat]

entry that specifies a specific git repo and commit for a dependent package?  My use case for this is HDF5. v0.14.3 has a feature that I need, but also a bug that was fixed in a subsequent commit but is not yet in a tagged version.  I know this info is captured in the
Manifest.toml
file, but that includes lots of additional details that don't seem necessary (see previous question)

messages.text:
1. There is some discussion about it here: <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/issues/1962>

2. For packages that are only really used as libraries, there isn't that much point in comitting it. But for anything where you want to be able to reproduce some result, they are great to have available.

3. No, only versions are available in `[compat]`. The compat info is used by the resolver and works purely by versions. There has been discussions of being able to depend on unregistered packages (see e.g. <https://github.com/JuliaLang/Pkg.jl/pull/1628>). but nothing super concrete yet.

elements.text: 1. There is some discussion about it here:

2. For packages that are only really used as libraries, there isn't that much point in comitting it. But for anything where you want to be able to reproduce some result, they are great to have available.

3. No, only versions are available in
[compat]
. The compat info is used by the resolver and works purely by versions. There has been discussions of being able to depend on unregistered packages (see e.g.
). but nothing super concrete yet.

messages.text: If a Julia package (say Foo) depends on other the master branch of other Julia packages, is it wise to commit the Manifest.toml file into the git repo for package Foo?

elements.text: If a Julia package (say Foo) depends on other the master branch of other Julia packages, is it wise to commit the Manifest.toml file into the git repo for package Foo?

messages.text: When should or shouldn't one commit the Manifest.toml into a git repo?

elements.text: When should or shouldn't one commit the Manifest.toml into a git repo?

messages.text: I read the discourse conversation regarding this, and the answer was when a Julia package is a library don't add it and when it is an application do add it.

elements.text: I read the discourse conversation regarding this, and the answer was when a Julia package is a library don't add it and when it is an application do add it.

messages.text: And people also mentioned something about CI causing issues if there's a Manifest.toml file in the repo.

elements.text: And people also mentioned something about CI causing issues if there's a Manifest.toml file in the repo.

messages.text: Can someone expand on this?

elements.text: Can someone expand on this?

messages.text: Thanks

elements.text: Thanks

messages.text: Manifests are irrelevant when installing packages (e.g., if Foo.jl has a Manifest.toml, `Pkg.add("Foo")` will completely ignore it). I'm pretty sure registered packages have to depend on registered versions of packages (so Foo.jl can't depend on `Bar#someotherbranch`, it has to depend on a released version of `Bar.jl`).

elements.text: Manifests are irrelevant when installing packages (e.g., if Foo.jl has a Manifest.toml,
Pkg.add("Foo")
will completely ignore it). I'm pretty sure registered packages have to depend on registered versions of packages (so Foo.jl can't depend on
Bar#someotherbranch
, it has to depend on a released version of
Bar.jl

messages.text: Manifests can sometimes cause issues with CI testing across different versions of Julia (e.g., if your manifest was generated using Julia 1.5, it might not work on 1.0 because some dependency doesn't actually work on 1.0).

elements.text: Manifests can sometimes cause issues with CI testing across different versions of Julia (e.g., if your manifest was generated using Julia 1.5, it might not work on 1.0 because some dependency doesn't actually work on 1.0).

messages.text: Manifests are useful for applications (as opposed to libraries) because you want to be confident that you're getting exactly the same environment (whether that be dev vs prod for something like a web-app, or even just making sure you get the same results on your laptop vs a colleagues laptop). It's incredibly frustrating to have small changes in transitive dependencies break your code, and including Manifest.toml can prevent that.

elements.text: Manifests are useful for applications (as opposed to libraries) because you want to be confident that you're getting exactly the same environment (whether that be dev vs prod for something like a web-app, or even just making sure you get the same results on your laptop vs a colleagues laptop). It's incredibly frustrating to have small changes in transitive dependencies break your code, and including Manifest.toml can prevent that.

messages.text: tl;dr: Don't include a Manifest.toml in your repo if it's a package. Do include a Manifest.toml when creating apps (including notebooks and reproducible scripts -- basically anything that's not a package).

elements.text: tl;dr: Don't include a Manifest.toml in your repo if it's a package. Do include a Manifest.toml when creating apps (including notebooks and reproducible scripts -- basically anything that's not a package).

messages.text: Thanks for the detail answers. I think I wasn't aware that registered packages need to depend on other registered packages.

elements.text: Thanks for the detail answers. I think I wasn't aware that registered packages need to depend on other registered packages.

messages.text:
Hey all. I want to fork a foo package and take it towards a different objective thereby creating a new package bar. The creator of foo has agreed to it. I have came across many instances where this if wrongly done leads to violations of the MIT license.
So what do you think is the "ethical" way of doing it?
I especially want to preserve the commit history in particular which shows that it is a fork of the foo package.

elements.text:
Hey all. I want to fork a foo package and take it towards a different objective thereby creating a new package bar. The creator of foo has agreed to it. I have came across many instances where this if wrongly done leads to violations of the MIT license.
So what do you think is the "ethical" way of doing it?
I especially want to preserve the commit history in particular which shows that it is a fork of the foo package.

GR and HTTP are circularly downgrading each other. Is this normal?
```(@v1.5) pkg> add GR@0.52.0
  Resolving package versions...
Updating `C:\Users\avik\.julia\environments\v1.5\Project.toml`
  [28b8d3ca] + GR v0.52.0
Updating `C:\Users\avik\.julia\environments\v1.5\Manifest.toml`
  [28b8d3ca] ↑ GR v0.49.1 ⇒ v0.52.0
  [cd3eb016] ↓ HTTP v0.9.2 ⇒ v0.8.19
  [5c2747f8] - URIs v1.1.0

(@v1.5) pkg> add HTTP@0.9.2
  Resolving package versions...
Updating `C:\Users\avik\.julia\environments\v1.5\Project.toml`
  [28b8d3ca] ↓ GR v0.52.0 ⇒ v0.49.1
  [cd3eb016] + HTTP v0.9.2
Updating `C:\Users\avik\.julia\environments\v1.5\Manifest.toml`
  [28b8d3ca] ↓ GR v0.52.0 ⇒ v0.49.1
  [cd3eb016] ↑ HTTP v0.8.19 ⇒ v0.9.2
  [5c2747f8] + URIs v1.1.0```

messages.text: Hello, given a module `M` and the `deps,compat` of a `Project.toml` file that define a set of packages, I'd like to be able to make those packages available to be `using`'d in that module `M` (dynamically, i.e. without hardcoding all of this in a file). I asked the question <https://discourse.julialang.org/t/loading-packages-programmatically-in-a-different-module/52777|on discourse>, thought it is probably related to `Pkg` and worth a ping here too?

attachments.title: Loading packages programmatically in a different module
attachments.text: Hello, for an experimental idea I would like to try to create and manipulate modules on the fly, including letting them use packages. I’m struggling to understand/get hints from the docs about this, so I wanted to ask for any pointers on the following: how do you use the Pkg machinery to calculate a set of packages given the deps and compat of a Project.toml file? how do you load a given package in a foreign module? Here’s my aspirational pseudo-code marked with # ???, grateful for any corre...

messages.text:
I understand it takes some time till new versions get to the storage server.
I think it would be nice if there was option to set "download newest suitable version present in package server" instead of defaulting to github.
I understand that for most usecases it's best way to default to <http://github.com|github.com>, but e.g. behind corporate firewall, where we have only the package server whitelisted, I would rather use older version of library (if it will satisfy the compat) than having the CI fail because it can't reach <http://github.com|github.com>.

Should I fill such feature as an issue to Pkg.jl?
I think it's quite important if a company want to use Julia in a controlled environment.

messages.text:
Is there an "official" way of generating precompile statements from the unit tests of a package `X`?
I've tried to run
```julia --project --trace-compile=precompile.jl -e 'using Pkg; Pkg.test()'```
but the resulting `precompile.jl` is only ~80 lines, and doesn't include any statement related to `X`.
I have several test-specific dependencies, thus the "naive"
```julia --project --trace-compile=precompile.jl test/runtests.jl```
doesn't work unless I manually add all those dependencies in my current environment (which kind of defeats the purpose of test-specific deps).

messages.text:
tests in BinaryBuilder are behaving in a particular weird way

* this is the `julia` command, if uses `--project`: <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilder.jl/blob/696d9f9ad1c5a105b1b369a1f45b88a6647b790d/azure-pipelines.yml#L13>
* we update the registry (not the packages), run `instantiate` and then the tests: <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilder.jl/blob/696d9f9ad1c5a105b1b369a1f45b88a6647b790d/azure-pipelines.yml#L50>
* even though the manifest has JLLWrappers v1.2.0 <https://github.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilder.jl/blob/696d9f9ad1c5a105b1b369a1f45b88a6647b790d/Manifest.toml#L125-L128>, some jobs fail because they have JLLWrappers v1.1.3: <https://dev.azure.com/JuliaPackaging/BinaryBuilder.jl/_build/results?buildId=8353&view=logs&j=aaebf0e6-d7cd-53db-6fd2-ebe168039a5a&t=231c1df8-60d4-55f6-9e92-9b8d8520ea6c&l=65> (not even v1.1.4)

any idea of what's going on?

Then you need the UUID:

```julia> pkgid = Base.PkgId(Base.UUID("69de0a69-1ddd-5017-9359-2bf0b02dc9f0"), "Parsers")
Parsers [69de0a69-1ddd-5017-9359-2bf0b02dc9f0]

julia> Base.locate_package(pkgid)
"/home/kc/.julia/packages/Parsers/2MBHI/src/Parsers.jl"```

elements.text: Then you need the UUID:

julia> pkgid = Base.PkgId(Base.UUID("69de0a69-1ddd-5017-9359-2bf0b02dc9f0"), "Parsers")
Parsers [69de0a69-1ddd-5017-9359-2bf0b02dc9f0]

julia> Base.locate_package(pkgid)
"/home/kc/.julia/packages/Parsers/2MBHI/src/Parsers.jl"

messages.text:
When a package `P` is registered in two registries, `add P` correctly installs the latest available version.
However, `dev P` seems to take the git url from the first registry, either in the order of how registries were added or alphabetically.
Is there any fix/workaround for this, to use the registry with latest version when `dev`ing as well?

elements.text: When a package
P
is registered in two registries,
add P

correctly installs the latest available version.
However,
dev P

seems to take the git url from the first registry, either in the order of how registries were added or alphabetically.
Is there any fix/workaround for this, to use the registry with latest version when
dev
ing as well?

messages.text: Is it possible to "develop" a package without having the package manager attempting to download the latest version of the dependencies? I think this is the same as add(...; preserve=PRESERVE_ALL)?

elements.text: Is it possible to "develop" a package without having the package manager attempting to download the latest version of the dependencies? I think this is the same as add(...; preserve=PRESERVE_ALL)?

messages.text: `Pkg.develop` accepts the `preserve` keyword argument, just like `Pkg.add`

elements.text: Pkg.develop
accepts the
preserve
keyword argument, just like
Pkg.add

messages.text: Does that work for your use case?

elements.text: Does that work for your use case?

messages.text: It probably will, thanks! I did not see it on the documentation so I thought it would not be possible...

elements.text: It probably will, thanks! I did not see it on the documentation so I thought it would not be possible...

messages.text: Yeah for some reason it's not listed in the documentation.

elements.text: Yeah for some reason it's not listed in the documentation.

messages.text: The command works. However, I was expecting that the package manager would not attempt to download packages that are already in the depot. It still does...

elements.text: The command works. However, I was expecting that the package manager would not attempt to download packages that are already in the depot. It still does...

messages.text: Their probably at different versions

elements.text: Their probably at different versions

messages.text: Yeah, that must be the case somehow.

elements.text: Yeah, that must be the case somehow.

messages.text: Still strange. I instantiated a package environment that includes a manifest. The package is fully functional when used from that env. Then, I try to dev the package in the main env and it still tries to download.

elements.text: Still strange. I instantiated a package environment that includes a manifest. The package is fully functional when used from that env. Then, I try to dev the package in the main env and it still tries to download.

messages.text: When you dev a package, it doesn't look at the manifest of that package environment.

elements.text: When you dev a package, it doesn't look at the manifest of that package environment.

messages.text: If you are deving in the main environment, it only looks at the manifest if the main environment

elements.text: If you are deving in the main environment, it only looks at the manifest if the main environment

messages.text: In general, package operations in environment X will only look at the manifest of environment X. Not any other manifests.

elements.text: In general, package operations in environment X will only look at the manifest of environment X. Not any other manifests.

messages.text: So if you Pkg.develop in environment X, and you pass the preserve kwarg to Pkg.develop, then the preservation is done with respect to the manifest of environment X only

elements.text: So if you Pkg.develop in environment X, and you pass the preserve kwarg to Pkg.develop, then the preservation is done with respect to the manifest of environment X only

messages.text: Mmm. Perhaps I should use the offline mode of the package manager then.

elements.text: Mmm. Perhaps I should use the offline mode of the package manager then.

messages.text: Yeah that might work. Just do `Pkg.offline(true)`

elements.text: Yeah that might work. Just do
Pkg.offline(true)

messages.text: Just out of curiosity, is your main environment empty? Or do you have other stuff in it?

elements.text: Just out of curiosity, is your main environment empty? Or do you have other stuff in it?

messages.text: It is pretty much empty, but not completely.

elements.text: It is pretty much empty, but not completely.

messages.text: Yeah so in that case, if you do Pkg.develop in the main environment, and you pass the preserve kwarg as PRESERVE_all, then Pkg is forced to preserve the current manifest in the main environment. So in the main environment, you have additional constraints. In the package environment, you don't have those constraints. So it makes sense that the two different environments might resolve to different sets of versions.

elements.text: Yeah so in that case, if you do Pkg.develop in the main environment, and you pass the preserve kwarg as PRESERVE_all, then Pkg is forced to preserve the current manifest in the main environment. So in the main environment, you have additional constraints. In the package environment, you don't have those constraints. So it makes sense that the two different environments might resolve to different sets of versions.

messages.text: Anyway, if your main interest is to minimize the number of downloads, then `Pkg.offline(true)` is probably your best bet.

elements.text: Anyway, if your main interest is to minimize the number of downloads, then
Pkg.offline(true)
is probably your best bet.

messages.text: Got it. Thanks a lot for your help!

elements.text: Got it. Thanks a lot for your help!

attachments.fallback:
[January 26th, 2021 6:16 PM] mmiller212365: I'm having some difficulty understanding how `LOAD_PATH` works. If I push a directory to it that has a `Manifest.toml`, the dependencies of that directory are accessible. If I delete the `Manifest.toml` from that directory, the dependencies are not accessible. At least I think this is what is happening...

Is this expected or not? The related issue is: <https://github.com/JuliaTesting/TestReports.jl/issues/53> if anyone's interested. I'm trying to ensure that the dependencies of `TestReports` are in the sandbox environment used to generate the test reports for other packages. Cheers!
attachments.text:
I'm having some difficulty understanding how `LOAD_PATH` works. If I push a directory to it that has a `Manifest.toml`, the dependencies of that directory are accessible. If I delete the `Manifest.toml` from that directory, the dependencies are not accessible. At least I think this is what is happening...

Is this expected or not? The related issue is: <https://github.com/JuliaTesting/TestReports.jl/issues/53> if anyone's interested. I'm trying to ensure that the dependencies of `TestReports` are in the sandbox environment used to generate the test reports for other packages. Cheers!

messages.text:
I’m seeing a weird issue in a class I teach. Students with new M1 Macbooks seem to have issues instantiating some packages. I can’t reproduce since I have an older Mac.

They activated/instantiated the Project.toml in <https://github.com/jlchan/caam452_s21/tree/main/hw1> (just adds UnicodePlots.jl and GarbageMath.jl). They get the error “expected package to be registered”

Has anyone else run into this? Would anyone with an M1 Mac be willing to reproduce this issue?
